title-group.article-title: Performance analysis of a 500 MWe coal-fired power plant with a post-combustion CO2 capture process

abstract.p: In this study, a performance analysis of a 500 MWe coal-fired power plant with a post-combustion CO2 capture system was performed. The amine-based chemical absorption process was considered as a base CO2 capture system. Based on the design conditions of the flue gas from the supercritical coal-fired power plant operating in the Republic of Korea, the energy consumption of the CO2 capture system was simulated using a process simulator. The simulation of the CO2 capture system was undertaken using Aspen Plus software with ELECNRTL property packages; based on these results, the energy requirement of the CO2 capture system and the overall efficiency of a power plant with the CO2 capture system was estimated. It was observed that the thermal energy required to regenerate the solvent reduces the efficiency of the power plant by 8.36%, the energy required to compress the CO2 from 0.1 to 11 MPa is the next largest factor, reducing the efficiency by 3.59%, and the other energy requirement amounts to 0.45%.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Capturing the CO2 from the flue gas of coal-fired power plants is of great concern due to its large quantity and its effects on the global environment. It is reported that in 2007, the total emissions from approximately 1000 coal-fired power plants globally were 7.9 Gt CO2. This is approximately 27% of the total global CO2 emissions.1 Based on the size of the CO2 emission, coal-fired power plants are drawing increasing interest as promising targets for the control of greenhouse gas emissions.

To capture the CO2 from the flue gas of coal-fired power plants, there are many technology-based options: chemical and physical absorption, cryogenic separation, solid sorbents, biotechnology, and membranes. In these options, it has been considered that amine-based CO2 absorption systems is one of the most likely near-term options for post-combustion CO2 capture: they can be used to dilute the CO2 stream systems, such as coal combustion flue gases, which contain only 10–12% CO2 by volume. The technology is commercially available; furthermore, it can be retrofitted to the existing power plants.2 However, in the operation of the existing post-combustion CO2 capture systems, the electricity output of the power plant is reduced because steam is taken from the turbine to provide the energy required for the solvent regeneration. Also, additional power consumption is required for the operation of the CO2 compressors and auxiliary equipment.

An estimation of the overall energy penalty of a power plant with a CO2 capture is critical to the economic analysis and practical feasibility study of retrofitting a CO2 capture to an existing plant. Some research groups have already performed techno-economic studies of the coal-fired power plant with CO2 capture.

Amrollahi et al.3 analyzed the effects of adding a CO2 capture system to a natural gas fired combined cycle power plant using UniSim Design (for the chemical absorption process simulation) and GT PRO (for the natural gas combined cycle design). They calculated an overall energy efficiency penalty by adding a CO2 capture and compression system to a natural gas fired combined cycle power as 7.1% points.

Lucquiaud and Gibbins4 evaluated the energy penalty through an extensive integration study of the capture process with a power block using the equation-based software gPROMs. They evaluated the energy penalty and CO2 abatement cost of supercritical and subcritical power plants with CO2 capture systems.4

In this study, a novel methodology for the performance analysis of coal-fired power plant was developed. Instead of using extensive thermodynamic calculations of the CO2 capture system integrated with a power block, simulations of the chemical absorption process were performed using Aspen Plus software (Aspen Technology, Inc.) with electrolyte NRTL (ELECNRTL) property packages. Based on the simulation results, the overall energy penalty of a power plant with the CO2 capture system was evaluated.

sec.title: Post-combustion CO2 capture system
sec.p:
The general process scheme for a coal-fired power plant with a post-combustion CO2 capture system is schematically shown in Figure 1. The heat generated from the combustion of the coal and feed air is used to generate steam at a high pressure, and electricity is produced by the steam moving through the steam turbines. The flue gas from the boiler is treated with a series of chemical processes that remove impurities (nitrogen, particulates, and sulfur oxide) and then undergoes the CO2 capture, where most of the CO2 in the flue gas is captured. Figure 1.
Schematic diagram of a coal-fired power plant with a post-combustion CO2 capture system.

sec.title: Chemical absorption process for post-combustion CO2 capture
CO2 capture
sec.p:
For the capture of CO2 from the flue gas, the amine-based CO2 absorption system is considered as one of the most likely near-term options. In Figure 2, the typical absorption process for the CO2 capture is shown. This process typically consists of an absorber and a stripper with other auxiliary equipment such as pumps, condensers, and exchangers. Each tower is generally filled with a packing material to enhance the reaction between the gas (flue gas) and the liquid (chemical solvent). Figure 2.
Process flow diagram for CO2 capture from the flue gas using a chemical solvent.

The flue gas from the pre-treatment process is introduced to the absorber. Then, the CO2 in the flue gas reacts counter-currently with the CO2-lean solution. The gases that do not react with the chemical solvent are emitted from the top of the absorber. The CO2-rich solution from the bottom of the absorber is transferred to the stripper via a lean/rich heat exchanger in which the CO2-rich solution is heated to between 80 ℃ and 90 ℃ and the CO2-lean that is discharged from the bottom of the stripper is simultaneously cooled.

In the stripper, the CO2 and monoethanolamine (MEA) solutions are separated from the CO2-rich MEA solution by heating at elevated temperatures (110–120 ℃). The heat used to transform the CO2-rich MEA solution to a CO2-lean one is extracted from the turbine of the power plant.

sec.title: CO2 compression
sec.p:
The captured CO2 stream from the stripper moves into the compression section where the CO2 is compressed from near atmospheric pressure to approximately 11–15 MPa for storage. In this part, most of the water in the flue gas is also removed to avoid gas hydrates, water freezing, and pipe line corrosion during transportation and storage.5 In Figure 3, the general compressor train for CO2 compression to transport is illustrated. The CO2 gas from the stripper is compressed using a centrifugal compressor and the compressed gas moves into the intercooler, where the water is condensed and removed through the vapor–liquid drum. The number of stages required depends on the final discharge pressure, gas composition, and utility cost. In this study, for the simulation of compression, four compressor stages with intercoolers are considered. In addition, the specifications of the discharge pressure and polytropic efficiencies of each stage are presented in Table 1. The following data are from the report of the CAESAR, CESAR, and DECARBit FP7 project.6 Figure 3.

sec.title: Energy penalty of power plants with CO2 capture
Steam extraction from power plants
sec.p:
To operate the CO2 capture system, a large amount of energy is required, which is supplied from the power plant. Figure 4 shows the general power plant steam cycle with CO2 capture. The energy required for the operation of the stripper reboiler is provided by the condensing steam extracted from the crossover pipe between the intermediate and low pressure turbine cylinders. The extracted steam is used to regenerate the solvent in the stripper, and the condensation from the reboiler can be used to preheat the feed water.4 Figure 4.
Steam cycle configuration with steam extraction for CO2 capture.

To evaluate the overall energy penalty of a power plant with CO2 capture, the thermal energy used for the regeneration of the chemical solvent (expressed in GJ/ton CO2) should be translated to the equivalent energy loss (kWh). This can be achieved through an extensive integration study of the CO2 capture with a power block.

In this article, instead of using previous approaches, the method originally developed by the Bolland and Undrum7 was adopted. They evaluated a convenient method to translate the thermal energy into the equivalent energy loss using a power factor, which is the figure dividing the energy output per mole of steam by the energy content of the steam in the same conditions. They also demonstrated the dependency of this factor on the steam temperature, as presented in Table 2. Table 2.
Power factor values suggested by Bolland et al.
Power factor Regeneration temperature (℃)
0.203 130
0.186 120
0.167 110

For a typical chemical absorption process using 30 wt% MEA solution, the normal operating temperature of the reboiler is approximately 120 ℃. Thus, in the further analysis presented in this article, 0.186 was used as the power factor.

sec.title: Calculation of energy penalty
sec.p:
The overall energy penalty of the power plant with CO2 capture can be calculated based on the figure of the total energy loss (Pcapture) for the operation of the CO2 capture system. Furthermore, Pcapture can be estimated using the summation of the energy loss due to the steam extraction (Preg) and mechanical work for the operation of the CO2 compression (Pcomp) and auxiliary equipment (Pauxiliary), respectively. (1)Pcapture=Preg+Pcomp+Pauxiliary Preg can be calculated as follows. (2)Preg=FpowerEreg where Fpower is the power factor and Ereg the thermal energy required for the solvent regeneration expressed in GJ/ton CO2. The overall energy penalty (ηpenalty) of the power plant with CO2 capture can be then calculated using equations (3) to (5) (3)Einput=Wnet/η
(4)η*=(Wnet-WnetPcapture/WCO2)Einput
(5)ηpenalty=η-η* where Einput is the fuel feed rate without the CO2 capture, Wnet the net power output of the power plant without the CO2 capture, and WCO2 the mass flow rate of the CO2 captured in the process. Also, η and η* indicate the plant efficiency without/with a CO2 capture system, respectively.

sec.title: Column model
sec.p: The process simulation of the baseline case was performed using the Aspen Plus software package (version 7.1). The absorber and stripper were simulated using five and eight equilibrium stages, respectively, of the RadFrac model which is suitable for the simulation of the absorption and stripping processes. Chemical absorption of CO2 in amine/water solvent involves electrolyte chemistry to capture the CO2 from the vapor phase to form a bicarbonate in the liquid phase. Thus in this article, the thermodynamic and transport properties were modeled using an ELECNRTL property method, which is the most versatile electrolyte property method and can handle both aqueous and polar reactions such as sour gas treating processes. In the ELECNRTL calculation, the NRTL method is used to calculate the liquid phase activity coefficient and the Redlich–Kwong method for the vapor phase fugacity coefficient calculation.10
For the simulation of column, the following equilibrium reactions are assumed to take place between CO2 and MEA.
Hydrolysis reaction (6)CO2+2H2O↔HCO3 -+H3O+
Carbamate reaction (7)MEACOO-+H2O↔MEA+HCO3 -
To converge a RadFrac model in a process simulation, strongly non-ideal liquid algorithm and the damping to stabilize convergence were used.

sec.title: Flow sheet
sec.p: For the evaluation of the overall performance of the CO2 capture process, the energy required for solvent regeneration (or regeneration energy, Hregen) could be calculated as a ratio of the reboiler heat duty (Qreboiler) and the mass flow rate of CO2 captured in the process (WCO2).11 (8)Hregen=QreboilerWCO2

Also, the values of CO2 loading of lean and rich MEA solutions, which are also the key parameters of the process operation, were calculated as a molar ratio of CO2 and MEA at the bottom of the stripper and absorber, respectively. In Table 5, the basic conditions for the simulation of the CO2 capture system are summarized. For the compression of CO2, most international studies on CO2 capture are based on CO2 delivery pressures of 11.0 MPa and the same pressure is adopted in this analysis. sec.title: Process simulation results
sec.p:
The simulation results of the baseline case are presented in Table 6. Based on the guidelines published by the IEA Greenhouse Gas R&D Programme, the operating conditions under which the CO2 removal rate shows almost 90% was found by changing of the solvent flow rate.8 Table 6.

It was calculated that the rich CO2 loadings were 0.48 mol CO2/mol MEA and the lean CO2 loading 0.22 CO2/mol MEA, and the regeneration energy requirement was analyzed as 4.09 GJ/ton CO2. This result is in good agreement with the numerical values reported in literature. For example, the Fluor’s Econamine FG™ process requires 4.2 GJ/ton CO2.12

sec.title: Calculation of efficiency penalty
sec.p: The overall energy penalty of the power plant with CO2 capture was calculated based on the total energy loss for the operation of the CO2 capture system. The total energy loss was estimated by summing the energy loss caused by the steam extraction for the solvent regeneration at the stripper and mechanical work required in order to operate the CO2 compression and auxiliary equipment, respectively.

sec.title: Energy loss for the extraction of low-pressure steam from the steam turbine
sec.p:
In principle, the regeneration energy of the amine solution can be defined as the summation of the reaction enthalpy between the amine solution and the CO2, the sensible heat for heating the CO2-loaded amine solution to the reboiler temperature and the latent heat of vaporization to generate the vapor. It was shown that the thermal energy required for the regeneration exceeded half of the total capture energy.11 In this article, for the evaluation of the energy loss for the extraction of low-pressure steam, the thermal energy used for the regeneration of the chemical solvent expressed in GJ/ton CO2 was translated to the equivalent energy loss (kWh) using a power factor (equation (2)). In Table 7, the result of the energy loss caused by the low pressure steam extraction (Preg) is shown. Table 7.

sec.title: Energy loss for compressing the captured CO2 to storage
sec.p:
For the calculation of energy loss for compressing the CO2, four compressor stages with intercoolers up to 11.0 MPa were considered. In addition, based on these conditions, the electricity requirement for the operation of each compressor stage was calculated. Using these data, total energy consumption for the operation of the compressor train (Pcomp) was calculated as a ratio of the sum of energy consumption of each compressor stage and the mass flow rate of CO2 captured in the process, as presented in Table 8. It demonstrates that the electricity requirement for CO2 compression from near atmospheric pressure to 11.0 MPa was analyzed to be 0.091 kWh/kg CO2. Also, this value shows that the energy loss (or energy consumption) for compressing CO2 is almost half of that of steam extraction. Table 8.

sec.title: Energy loss for the consumption of electricity in the CO2 capture process
sec.p:
There are also many auxiliary instruments required for the operation of the CO2 capture system. Based on the results of the simulation, the energy consumption of each auxiliary unit was calculated. Using this data, the energy consumption for the operation of the auxiliary equipment (Pauxiliary) was calculated, as in Table 9. The results show that the gas blower, which is required to overcome the pressure drop in the absorber, is a primary contributor to the energy consumption of the auxiliary equipment. Table 9.

sec.title: Calculation of the total efficiency penalties
sec.p:
Based on the previous analysis of energy loss during the operation of the CO2 capture process, the total efficiency penalty and the net power output of the power plant with CO2 capture was calculated using equations (1) to (5). It was shown that the net power output was reduced from 375 MWe (without capture) to 261 MWe (with capture) and the thermal energy required to regenerate the solvent reduced the efficiency by 8.36%; the energy required to compress CO2 from 0.1 to 11 MPa was the next largest factor, reducing the efficiency by 3.59%; and the other energy requirements amounted to 0.45%. Also, these results show that the steam consumption for the solvent regeneration accounts for about two-thirds of the total efficiency penalty (Table 10). Table 10.

Net power output (MWe) 375 261

Efficiency penalty for regeneration (%) 8.36
Efficiency penalty for capture (%) 0.45
Efficiency penalty for compression (%) 3.59

Based on the present methodology, a sensitivity analysis was also performed. In Table 11, the overall efficiency as a function of the regeneration energy is presented. For this analysis, the energy penalty for the consumption of the auxiliary equipment and compressing was assumed to have the same values in each case. It was calculated that as the regeneration energy becomes lower, the efficiency penalty also decreases and the power plant efficiency can be increased from 28.6% (base case) to 32.4% (case 2). From these results, it could be concluded that for the reduction of energy penalty of the power plant with the CO2 capture process, it should be focused on the development of a novel solvent with a lower regeneration energy. sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A performance analysis of a 500 MWe coal-fired power plant with a post-combustion CO2 capture system was performed. Based on a novel methodology for performance analysis of coal-fired power plants, the overall energy penalty of the power plant with the CO2 capture system using 30 wt% MEA as a chemical solvent was evaluated. It was observed that the thermal energy required to regenerate the solvent reduces the efficiency of the power plant by 8.36%; the energy required to compress CO2 from 0.1 to 11 MPa is the next largest factor, reducing the efficiency by 3.59%, and other energy requirements amount to 0.45%. Also, it shows that the steam consumption for solvent regeneration accounts for about two-thirds of the total efficiency penalty.
